speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: Your silence and attention, worthy friends,
That your free spirits may with more pleasing sense
Relish the life of this our active scene!
To which intent, to calm this murmuring breath,
We ring this round with our invoking spells;
If that your listening ears be yet prepar’d
To entertain the subject of our play,
Lend us your patience!
’Tis Peter Fabel, a renownèd scholar,
Whose fame hath still been hitherto forgot
By all the writers of this latter age.
In Middlesex his birth and his abode,
Not full seven mile from this great famous city;
That, for his fame in sleights and magic won,
Was call’d the merry Fiend of Edmonton.
If any here make doubt of such a name,
In Edmonton yet fresh unto this day,
Fix’d in the wall of that old antient church,
His monument remaineth to be seen;
His memory yet in the mouths of men,
That whilst he liv’d he could deceive the Devil.
Imagine now that whilst he is retir’d
From Cambridge back unto his native home,
Suppose the silent, sable-visag’d night
Casts her black curtain over all the world;
And whilst he sleeps within his silent bed,
Toil’d with the studies of the passèd day,
The very time and hour wherein that spirit
That many years attended his command,
And oftentimes ’twixt Cambridge and that town
Had in a minute borne him through the air,
By composition ’twixt the fiend and him,
Comes now to claim the scholar for his due.
Behold him here, laid on his restless couch,
His fatal chime preparèd at his head,
His chamber guarded with these sable sleights,
And by him stands that necromantic chair,
In which he makes his direful invocations,
And binds the fiends that shall obey his will.
Sit with a pleasèd eye, until you know
The comic end of our sad tragic show.

stagedir.dir: The chime goes, in which time Fabel is oft seen to stare about him, and hold up his hands.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: What means the tolling of this fatal chime?
O, what a trembling horror strikes my heart!
My stiffen’d hair stands upright on my head,
As do the bristles of a porcupine.

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: Fabel, awake! Or I will bear thee hence
Headlong to hell.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Ha, ha,
Why dost thou wake me? Coreb, is it thou?

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: ’Tis I.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: I know thee well: I hear the watchful dogs
With hollow howling tell of thy approach;
The lights burn dim, affrighted with thy presence;
And this distemper’d and tempestuous night
Tells me the air is troubled with some devil.

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: Come, art thou ready?

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Whither? Or to what?

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: Why, Scholar, this the hour my date expires;
I must depart, and come to claim my due.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Ha, what is thy due?

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: Fabel, thyself!

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: O, let not darkness hear thee speak that word,
Lest that with force it hurry hence amain,
And leave the world to look upon my woe:
Yet overwhelm me with this globe of earth,
And let a little sparrow with her bill
Take but so much as she can bear away,
That, every day thus losing of my load,
I may again in time yet hope to rise.

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: Didst thou not write thy name in thine own blood,
And drew’st the formal deed ’twixt thee and me,
And is it not recorded now in hell?

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Why com’st thou in this stern and horrid shape,
Not in familiar sort, as thou wast wont?

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: Because the date of thy command is out,
And I am master of thy skill and thee.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Coreb, thou angry and impatient spirit,
I have earnest business for a private friend;
Reserve me, spirit, until some further time.

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: I will not for the mines of all the earth.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Then let me rise, and ere I leave the world,
Dispatch some business that I have to do;
And in mean time repose thee in that chair.

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: Fabel, I will.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: O, that this soul, that cost so great a price
As the dear precious blood of her Redeemer,
Inspir’d with knowledge, should by that alone
Which makes a man so mean unto the powers,
Even lead him down into the depth of hell,
When men in their own pride strive to know more
Than man should know!
For this alone God cast the angels down.
The infinity of arts is like a sea,
Into which, when man will take in hand to sail
Further than reason, which should be his pilot,
Hath skill to guide him, losing once his compass,
He falleth to such deep and dangerous whirlpools,
As he doth lose the very sight of heaven:
The more he strives to come to quiet harbor,
The further still he finds himself from land.
Man, striving still to find the depth of evil,
Seeking to be a God, becomes a devil.

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: Come, Fabel, hast thou done?

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Yes, yes. Come hither!

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: Fabel, I cannot.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Cannot?—What ails your hollowness?

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: Good Fabel, help me!

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Alas! Where lies your grief? Some Aqua-vitae!
The Devil’s very sick, I fear he’ll die;
For he looks very ill.

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: Dar’st thou deride the minister of darkness?
In Lucifer’s dread name Coreb conjures thee
To set him free.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: I will not for the mines of all the earth,
Unless thou give me liberty to see
Seven years more, before thou seize on me.

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: Fabel, I give it thee.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Swear, damnèd fiend!

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: Unbind me, and by hell I will not touch thee,
Till seven years from this hour be full expir’d.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Enough, come out.

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: A vengeance take thy art!
Live and convert all piety to evil:
Never did man thus over-reach the Devil.
No time on earth like Phaetonic flames
Can have perpetual being. I’ll return
To my infernal mansion; but be sure,
Thy seven years done, no trick shall make me tarry,
But, Coreb, thou to hell shalt Fabel carry.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Then, thus betwixt us two this variance ends,
Thou to thy fellow fiends, I to my friends!

scene.scenelocation: Before the St. George Inn in Waltham.

stagedir.dir: Enter Sir Arthur Clare, Dorcas, his lady, Millicent, his daughter, young Harry Clare; the men booted, the Gentlewomen in cloaks and safeguards. Blague, the merry Host of the George, comes in with them.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Welcome, good knight, to the George at Waltham, my free-hold, my tenements, goods and chattels! Madam, here’s a room is the very Homer and Iliads of a lodging, it hath none of the four elements in it; I built it out of the center, and I drink ne’er the less sack. Welcome, my little waste of maiden-heads! What? I serve the good Duke of Norfolk.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: God-a-mercy, my good host Blague! Thou hast a good seat here.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: ’Tis correspondent or so: there’s not a Tartarian nor a carrier shall breathe upon your geldings; they have villainous rank feet, the rogues, and they shall not sweat in my linen. Knights and lords too have been drunk in my house, I thank the destinies.

speech.speaker: Y. CLARE.
speech.line: Prithee, good sinful innkeeper, will that corruption, thine ostler, look well to my gelding. Hey, a pox of these rushes!

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: You, Saint Dennis, your gelding shall walk without doors, and cool his feet for his master’s sake. By the body of St. George, I have an excellent intellect to go steal some venison. Now, when wast thou in the forest?

speech.speaker: Y. CLARE.
speech.line: Away, you stale mess of white broth! Come hither, sister, let me help you.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Mine host, is not Sir Richard Mounchensey come yet, according to our appointment, when we last dined here?

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: The knight’s not yet apparent.—Marry, here’s a forerunner that summons a parle, and saith, he’ll be here top and top-gallant presently.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: ’Tis well. Good mine host, go down, and see breakfast be provided.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Knight, thy breath hath the force of a woman, it takes me down. I am for the baser element of the kitchen: I retire like a valiant soldier, face point blank to the foeman, or, like a courtier, that must not show the Prince his posteriors; I vanish to know my canvasadoes, and my interrogatories, for I serve the good Duke of Norfolk.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: How doth my Lady? Are you not weary, madam?
Come hither, I must talk in private with you;
My daughter Millicent must not overhear.

speech.speaker: MIL.
speech.line: Ay, whispering? Pray God it tend my good!
Strange fear assails my heart, usurps my blood.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: You know our meeting with the knight Mounchensey
Is to assure our daughter to his heir.

speech.speaker: L. DOR.
speech.line: ’Tis, without question.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Two tedious winters have past o’er, since first
These couple lov’d each other, and in passion
Glued first their naked hands with youthful moisture—
Just so long, on my knowledge.

speech.speaker: L. DOR.
speech.line: And what of this?

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: This morning should my daughter lose her name,
And to Mounchensey’s house convey our arms,
Quarter’d within his ’scutcheon; th’ affiance, made
’Twixt him and her, this morning should be seal’d.

speech.speaker: L. DOR.
speech.line: I know it should.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: But there are crosses, wife; here’s one in Waltham,
Another at the Abbey, and the third
At Cheston; and ’tis ominous to pass
Any of these without a pater-noster.
Crosses of love still thwart this marriage,
Whilst that we two, like spirits, walk in night
About those stony and hard-hearted plots.

speech.speaker: MIL.
speech.line: O God, what means my father?

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: For look you, wife, the riotous old knight
Hath overrun his annual revenue
In keeping jolly Christmas all the year:
The nostrils of his chimney are still stuff’d
With smoke, more chargeable than cane-tobacco:
His hawks devour his fattest hogs, whilst Simple,
His leanest cur, eat his hounds’ carrion.
Besides, I heard of late, his younger brother,
A Turkey merchant, hath sore suck’d the knight
By means of some great losses on the sea;
That, you conceive me, before God, all’s naught,
His seat is weak. Thus, each thing rightly scann’d,
You’ll see a flight, wife, shortly of his land.

speech.speaker: MIL.
speech.line: Treason to my heart’s truest sovereign!
How soon is love smothered in foggy gain!

speech.speaker: L. DOR.
speech.line: But how shall we prevent this dangerous match?

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: I have a plot, a trick, and this it is—
Under this color I’ll break off the match:
I’ll tell the knight that now my mind is chang’d
For marrying of my daughter: for I intend
To send her unto Cheston Nunnery.

speech.speaker: MIL.
speech.line: O me accurst!

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: There to become a most religious nun.

speech.speaker: MIL.
speech.line: I’ll first be buried quick.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: To spend her beauty in most private prayers.

speech.speaker: MIL.
speech.line: I’ll sooner be a sinner in forsaking
Mother and father.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: How dost like my plot?

speech.speaker: L. DOR.
speech.line: Exceeding well; but is it your intent
She shall continue there?

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Continue there? Ha, ha, that were a jest!
You know a virgin may continue there
A twelvemonth and a day only on trial.
There shall my daughter sojourn some three months,
And in meantime I’ll compass a fair match
’Twixt youthful Jerningham, the lusty heir
Of Sir Ralph Jerningham, dwelling in the forest.
I think they’ll both come hither with Mounchensey.

speech.speaker: L. DOR.
speech.line: Your care argues the love you bear our child;
I will subscribe to any thing you’ll have me.

speech.speaker: MIL.
speech.line: You will subscribe to it! Good, good, ’tis well;
Love hath two chairs of state, heaven and hell.
My dear Mounchensey, thou my death shalt rue,
Ere to my heart Millicent prove untrue.

scene.scenetime: Early morning a few minutes later.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Ostlers, you knaves and commanders, take the horses of the knights and competitors: your honorable hulks have put into harbor, they’ll take in fresh water here, and I have provided clean chamber-pots. Via, they come!

stagedir.dir: Enter Sir Richard Mounchensey, Sir Ralph Jerningham, young Frank Jerningham, Raymond Mounchensey, Peter Fabel, and Bilbo.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: The destinies be most neat chamberlains to these swaggering puritans, knights of the subsidy.

speech.speaker: RICH.
speech.line: God-a-mercy, good mine host.

speech.speaker: RALP.
speech.line: Thanks, good host Blague.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Room for my case of pistols, that have Greek and Latin bullets in them; let me cling to your flanks, my nimble Giberalters, and blow wind in your calves to make them swell bigger. Ha, I’ll caper in mine own fee-simple. Away with punctilios and orthography! I serve the good Duke of Norfolk. Bilbo, Tityre, tu patulæ recubans sub tegmine fagi.

speech.speaker: BILB.
speech.line: Truly, mine host, Bilbo, though he be somewhat out of fashion, will be your only blade still. I have a villainous sharp stomach to slice a breakfast.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Thou shalt have it without any more discontinuance, releases, or attournment. What! We know our terms of hunting and the sea-card.

speech.speaker: BILB.
speech.line: And do you serve the good Duke of Norfolk still?

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Still, and still, and still, my soldier of St. Quentin’s! Come, follow me; I have Charles’ wain below in a butt of sack, ’twill glister like your crab-fish.

speech.speaker: BILB.
speech.line: You have fine scholar-like terms; your Cooper’s Dictionary is your only book to study in a cellar, a man shall find very strange words in it. Come, my host, let’s serve the good Duke of Norfolk.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: And still, and still, and still, my boy, I’ll serve the good Duke of Norfolk.

stagedir.dir: Enter Sir Arthur Clare, Harry Clare, and Millicent.

speech.speaker: RALP.
speech.line: Good Sir Arthur Clare!

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: What gentleman is that? I know him not.

speech.speaker: RICH.
speech.line: ’Tis Master Fabel, sir, a Cambridge scholar,
My son’s dear friend.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Sir, I entreat you know me.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Command me, sir; I am affected to you
For your Mounchensey’s sake.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Alas, for him,
I not respect whether he sink or swim!
A word in private, Sir Ralph Jerningham.

speech.speaker: RAYM.
speech.line: Methinks your father looketh strangely on me:
Say, love, why are you sad?

speech.speaker: MIL.
speech.line: I am not, sweet;
Passion is strong, when woe with woe doth meet.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Shall’s in to breakfast? After we’ll conclude
The cause of this our coming: in and feed,
And let that usher a more serious deed.

speech.speaker: MIL.
speech.line: Whilst you desire his grief, my heart shall bleed.

speech.speaker: Y. JERN.
speech.line: Raymond Mounchesney, come, be frolic, friend,
This is the day thou hast expected long.

speech.speaker: RAYM.
speech.line: Pray God, dear Jerningham, it prove so happy.

speech.speaker: Y. JERN.
speech.line: There’s nought can alter it! Be merry, lad!

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: There’s nought shall alter it! Be lively, Raymond!
Stand any opposition ‘gainst thy hope,
Art shall confront it with her largest scope.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Good old Mounchensey, is thy hap so ill,
That for thy bounty and thy royal parts
Thy kind alliance should be held in scorn,
And after all these promises my Clare
Refuse to give his daughter to thy son,
Only because thy revenues cannot reach
To make her dowage of so rich a jointure
As can the heir of wealthy Jerningham?
And therefore is the false fox now in hand
To strike a match betwixt her and the other;
And the old grey-beards now are close together,
Plotting it in the garden. Is’t even so?
Raymond Mounchensey, boy, have thou and I
Thus long at Cambridge read the liberal arts,
The metaphysics, magic, and those parts
Of the most secret deep philosophy?
Have I so many melancholy nights
Watch’d on the top of Peter-house highest tower,
And come we back unto our native home,
For want of skill to lose the wench thou lov’st?
We’ll first hang Enfield in such rings of mist
As never rose from any dampish fen:
I’ll make the brinèd sea to rise at Ware,
And drown the marshes unto Stratford Bridge;
I’ll drive the deer from Waltham in their walks,
And scatter them like sheep in every field.
We may perhaps be cross’d; but, if we be,
He shall cross the Devil, that but crosses me.

stagedir.dir: Enter Raymond, Young Jerningham, and Young Clare.

speech.line: But here comes Raymond, disconsolate and sad,
And here’s the gallant that must have the wench.

speech.speaker: Y. JERN.
speech.line: I prithee, Raymond, leave these solemn dumps:
Revive thy spirits, thou that before hast been
More watchful than the day-proclaiming cock,
As sportive as a kid, as frank and merry
As Mirth herself!
If aught in me may thy content procure,
It is thine own, thou may’st thyself assure.

speech.speaker: RAYM.
speech.line: Ha, Jerningham, if any but thyself
Had spoke that word, it would have come as cold
As the bleak northern winds upon the face
Of winter.
From thee they have some power upon my blood;
Yet being from thee,—had but that hollow sound
Come from the lips of any living man,
It might have won the credit of mine ear;
From thee it cannot.

speech.speaker: Y. JERN.
speech.line: If I understand thee, I am a villain:
What, dost thou speak in parables to thy friends?

speech.speaker: Y. CLARE.
speech.line: Come, boy, and make me this same groaning love,—
Troubled with stitches and the cough a’th’ lungs,
That wept his eyes out when he was a child,
And ever since hath shot at hoodman-blind,—
Make her leap, caper, jerk, and laugh, and sing,
And play me horse-tricks;
Make Cupid wanton as his mother’s dove:
But in this sort, boy, I would have thee love.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Why, how now, madcap? What, my lusty Frank,
So near a wife, and will not tell your friend?
But you will to this gear in hugger-mugger;
Art thou turned miser, rascal, in thy loves?

speech.speaker: Y. JERN.
speech.line: Who, I? ’Sblood, what should all you see in me, that I should look like a married man, ha? Am I bald? Are my legs too little for my hose? If I feel anything in my forehead, I am a villain. Do I wear a nightcap? Do I bend in the hams? What dost thou see in me, that I should be towards marriage, ha?

speech.speaker: Y. CLARE.
speech.line: What, thou married? Let me look upon thee, rogue. Who has given out this of thee? How cam’st thou into this ill name? What company hast thou been in, rascal?

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: You are the man, sir, must have Millicent,
The match is making in the garden now;
Her jointure is agreed on, and th’ old men,
Your fathers, mean to launch their busy bags,
But in meantime to thrust Mounchensey off.
For color of this new intended match,
Fair Millicent to Cheston must be sent,
To take the approbation for a nun.
Ne’er look upon me, lad, the match is done.

speech.speaker: Y. JERN.
speech.line: Raymond Mounchensey, now I touch thy grief
With the true feeling of a zealous friend.
And as for fair and beauteous Millicent,
With my vain breath I will not seek to slubber
Her angel-like perfections; but thou know’st
That Essex hath the saint that I adore.
Where e’er did we meet thee and wanton springs,
That like a wag thou hast not laugh’d at me,
And with regardless jesting mock’d my love?
How many a sad and weary summer night
My sighs have drunk the dew from off the earth,
And I have taught the nightingale to wake,
And from the meadows sprung the early lark
An hour before she should have list to sing:
I have loaded the poor minutes with my moans,
That I have made the heavy slow-pac’d hours
To hang like heavy clogs upon the day.
But, dear Mounchensey, had not my affection
Seiz’d on the beauty of another dame,
Before I’d wrong the chase, and o’ergive th’ love
Of one so worthy and so true a friend,
I will abjure both beauty and her sight,
And will in love become a counterfeit.

speech.speaker: RAYM.
speech.line: Dear Jerningham, thou hast begot my life,
And from the mouth of hell, where now I sat,
I feel my spirit rebound against the stars:
Thou hast conquer’d me, dear friend; in my free soul
Neither time nor death can by their power control.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Frank Jerningham, thou art a gallant boy;
And were he not my pupil, I would say
He were as fine a mettled gentleman,
Of as free spirit, and of as fine a temper
As is in England; and he is a man
That very richly may deserve thy love.
But, noble Clare, this while of our discourse,
What may Mounchensey’s honor to thyself
Exact upon the measure of thy grace?

speech.speaker: Y. CLARE.
speech.line: Raymond Mounchensey? I would have thee know,
He does not breathe this air,
Whose love I cherish, and whose soul I love
More than Mounchensey’s:
Nor ever in my life did see the man
Whom, for his wit and many virtuous parts,
I think more worthy of my sister’s love.
But since the matter grows unto this pass,
I must not seem to cross my father’s will;
But when thou list to visit her by night,
My horse is saddled, and the stable door
Stands ready for thee; use them at thy pleasure.
In honest marriage wed her frankly, boy,
And if thou gett’st her, lad, God give thee joy!

speech.speaker: RAYM.
speech.line: Then, care, away! Let fates my fall pretend,
Back’d with the favors of so true a friend!

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Let us alone, to bustle for the set;
For age and craft with wit and art have met.
I’ll make my spirits to dance such nightly jigs
Along the way ’twixt this and Tot’nam cross,
The carriers’ jades shall cast their heavy packs,
And the strong hedges scarce shall keep them in:
The milkmaid’s cuts shall turn the wenches off,
And lay the dossers tumbling in the dust:
The frank and merry London ’prentices,
That come for cream and lusty country cheer,
Shall lose their way; and, scrambling in the ditches,
All night shall whoop and hollow, cry and call,
Yet none to other find the way at all.

speech.speaker: RAYM.
speech.line: Pursue the project, scholar: what we can do
To help endeavor, join our lives thereto!

stagedir.dir: Enter Banks, Sir John, and Smug.

speech.speaker: BANKS.
speech.line: Take me with you, good Sir John! A plague on thee, Smug! An thou touchest liquor, thou art foundered straight. What! Are your brains always water-mills? Must they ever run round?

speech.speaker: SMUG.
speech.line: Banks, your ale is a Philistine fox; heart, there’s fire i’ the tail on’t; you are a rogue to charge us with mugs i’th’ rearward. A plague of this wind; O, it tickles our catastrophe.

speech.speaker: JOHN.
speech.line: Neighbor Banks of Waltham, and Goodman Smug, the honest smith of Edmonton, as I dwell betwixt you both at Enfield, I know the taste of both your ale-houses. They are good both, smart both. Hem, grass and hay! We are all mortal Let’s live till we die, and be merry; and there’s an end.

speech.speaker: BANKS.
speech.line: Well said, Sir John, you are of the same humor still, and doth the water run the same way still, boy?

speech.speaker: SMUG.
speech.line: Vulcan was a rogue to him; Sir John, lock, lock, lock fast, Sir John; so, Sir John. I’ll one of these years, when it shall please the goddesses and the destinies, be drunk in your company; that’s all now, and God send us health. Shall I swear I love you?

speech.speaker: JOHN.
speech.line: No oaths, no oaths, good neighbor Smug;
We’ll wet our lips together and hug;

Carouse in private, and elevate the heart, and the liver and the lights—and the lights, mark you me, within us; for, hem, grass and hay! We are all mortal; let’s live till we die, and be merry; and there’s an end.

speech.speaker: BANKS.
speech.line: But to our former motion about stealing some venison; whither go we?

speech.speaker: JOHN.
speech.line: Into the forest, neighbor Banks, into Brian’s walk, the mad keeper.

speech.speaker: SMUG.
speech.line: ’Sblood! I’ll tickle your keeper.

speech.speaker: BANKS.
speech.line: I’faith, thou art always drunk when we have need of thee.

speech.speaker: SMUG.
speech.line: Need of me? ’sheart! You shall have need of me always, while there’s iron in an anvil.

speech.speaker: BANKS.
speech.line: Master Parson, may the smith go, think you, being in this taking?

speech.speaker: SMUG.
speech.line: Go? I’ll go in spite of all the bells in Waltham.

speech.speaker: JOHN.
speech.line: The question is, good neighbor Banks—let me see: the moon shines tonight,—there’s not a narrow bridge betwixt this and the forest,—his brain will be settled ere night; he may go, he may go, neighbor Banks. Now we want none but the company of mine host Blague of the George at Waltham; if he were here, our consort were full. Look where comes my good host, the Duke of Norfolk’s man! And how? And how? Ahem, grass and hay! We are not yet mortal; let’s live till we die, and be merry; and there’s an end.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Ha, my Castilian dialogues! And art thou in breath still, boy? Miller, doth the match hold? Smith, I see by thy eyes thou hast been reading little Geneva print: but wend we merrily to the forest, to steal some of the king’s deer! I’ll meet you at the time appointed. Away, I have knights and colonels at my house, and must tend the Hungarians. If we be scared in the forest, we’ll meet in the church-porch at Enfield. Is’t correspondent?

speech.speaker: BANKS.
speech.line: ’Tis well; but how, if any of us should be taken?

speech.speaker: SMUG.
speech.line: He shall have ransom, by the Lord.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Tush, the knave keepers are my bosonians and my pensioners. Nine o’clock! Be valiant, my little Gogmagogs; I’ll fence with all the justices in Hertfordshire. I’ll have a buck till I die; I’ll slay a doe while I live. Hold your bow straight and steady! I serve the good Duke of Norfolk.

speech.speaker: SMUG.
speech.line: O rare! Who-ho-ho, boy!

speech.speaker: JOHN.
speech.line: Peace, neighbor Smug! You see this is a boor, a boor of the country, an illiterate boor, and yet the citizen of good fellows. Come, let’s provide; ahem, grass and hay! We are not yet all mortal; we’ll live till we die, and be merry; and there’s an end. Come, Smug!

speech.speaker: SMUG.
speech.line: Good night, Waltham—who-ho-ho, boy!

scene.scenelocation: Before the St. George Inn in Waltham.

stagedir.dir: Enter Sirs Richard and Arthur, and Gentlemen from breakfast again.

speech.speaker: RICH.
speech.line: Nor I for thee, Clare, not of this.
What? Hast thou fed me all this while with shalls?
And com’st to tell me now thou lik’st it not?

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: I do not hold thy offer competent;
Nor do I like th’ assurance of thy land,
The title is so brangled with thy debts.

speech.speaker: RICH.
speech.line: Too good for thee; and, knight, thou knowest it well,
I fawn’d not on thee for thy goods, not I;
’Twas thine own motion; that thy wife doth know.

speech.speaker: L. DOR.
speech.line: Husband, it was so. He lies not in that.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Hold thy chat, quean.

speech.speaker: RICH.
speech.line: To which I hearken’d willingly, and the rather,
Because I was persuaded it proceeded
From love thou bor’st to me and to my boy;
And gav’st him free access unto thy house,
Where he hath not behav’d him to thy child
But as befits a gentleman to do:
Nor is my poor distressèd state so low,
That I’ll shut up my doors, I warrant thee.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Let it suffice, Mounchensey, I mislike it;
Nor think thy son a match fit for my child.

speech.speaker: RICH.
speech.line: I tell thee, Clare, his blood is good and clear,
As the best drop that panteth in thy veins:
But for this maid, thy fair and virtuous child,
She is no more disparag’d by thy baseness
Then the most orient and the precious jewel,
Which still retains his luster and his beauty,
Although a slave were owner of the same.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: She is the last is left me to bestow,
And her I mean to dedicate to God.

speech.speaker: RICH.
speech.line: You do, sir?

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Sir, sir, I do, she is mine own.

speech.speaker: RICH.
speech.line: And pity she is so!—
Damnation dog thee and thy wretched pelf!

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Not thou, Mounchensey, shalt bestow my child.

speech.speaker: RICH.
speech.line: Neither shalt thou bestow her where thou mean’st.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: What wilt thou do?

speech.speaker: RICH.
speech.line: No matter, let that be;
I will do that, perhaps, shall anger thee:
Thou hast wrong’d my love, and, by God’s blessed angel,
Thou shalt well know it.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Tut, brave not me!

speech.speaker: RICH.
speech.line: Brave thee, base churl! Were’t not for man-hood sake—
I say no more, but that there be some by
Whose blood is hotter then ours is,
Which, being stirr’d might make us both repent
This foolish meeting. But, Harry Clare,
Although thy father have abused my friendship,
Yet I love thee, I do, my noble boy,
I do, i’faith.

speech.speaker: L. DOR.
speech.line: Ay, do, do, fill all the world with talk of us, man. Man, I never look’d for better at your hands.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: I hoped your great experience and your years
Would have prov’d patience rather to your soul,
Than with this frantic and untamed passion
To whet their skeins. And, but for that
I hope their friendships are too well confirm’d,
And their minds temper’d with more kindly heat,
Than for their froward parents’ soars,
That they should break forth into public brawls.
Howe’er the rough hand of th’ untoward world
Hath molded your proceedings in this matter,
Yet I am sure the first intent was love:
Then since the first spring was so sweet and warm,
Let it die gently; ne’er kill it with a scorn.

speech.speaker: RAYM.
speech.line: O thou base world, how lep’rous is that soul
That is once lim’d in that polluted mud!
O Sir Arthur, you have startled his free active spirits
With a too sharp spur for his mind to bear.
Have patience, sir; the remedy to woe
Is to leave what of force we must forego.

speech.speaker: MIL.
speech.line: And I must take a twelvemonth’s approbation,
That in meantime this sole and private life
At the year’s end may fashion me a wife.
But, sweet Mounchensey, ere this year be done,
Thou’st be a friar, if that I be a nun.
And, father, ere young Jerningham’s I’ll be,
I will turn mad to spite both him and thee.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Wife, come to horse, and, huswife, make you ready;
For, if I live, I swear by this good light,
I’ll see you lodg’d in Cheston house tonight.

speech.speaker: RICH.
speech.line: Raymond, away! Thou seest how matters fall.
Churl, hell consume thee, and thy pelf, and all!

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Now, Master Clare, you see how matters fadge;
Your Millicent must needs be made a nun.
Well, sir, we are the men must ply this match:
Hold you your peace, and be a looker on,
And send her unto Cheston when he will,
I’ll send me fellows of a handful high
Into the cloisters where the nuns frequent,
Shall make them skip like does about the dale,
And make the lady prioress of the house
To play at leap-frog, naked in their smocks,
Until the merry wenches at their mass
Cry teehee weehee;
And tickling these mad lasses in their flanks,
Shall sprawl, and squeak, and pinch their fellow-nuns.
Be lively, boys, before the wench we lose,
I’ll make the abbess wear the canon’s hose.

stagedir.dir: Enter Henry Clare, Frank Jerningham, Peter Fabel, and Millicent.

speech.speaker: Y. CLARE.
speech.line: Spite now hath done her worst; sister, be patient!

speech.speaker: Y. JERN.
speech.line: Forewarn’d poor Raymond’s company! O heaven!
When the composure of weak frailty meet
Upon this mart of dirt, O then weak love
Must in her own unhappiness be silent,
And wink on all deformities.

speech.speaker: MIL.
speech.line: ’Tis well:
Where’s Raymond, brother? Where’s my dear Mounchensey?
Would we might weep together and then part;
Our sighing parle would much ease my heart.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Sweet beauty, fold your sorrows in the thought
Of future reconcilement. Let your tears
Show you a woman; but be no farther spent
Than from the eyes; for, sweet, experience says
That love is firm that’s flatter’d with delays.

speech.speaker: MIL.
speech.line: Alas, sir, think you I shall e’er be his?

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: As sure as parting smiles on future bliss.
Yond comes my friend! See, he hath doted
So long upon your beauty, that your want
Will with a pale retirement waste his blood;
For in true love music doth sweetly dwell:
Sever’d, these less worlds bear within them hell.

speech.speaker: RAYM.
speech.line: Harry and Frank, you are enjoined to wean
Your friendship from me; we must part; the breath
Of all advised corruption, pardon me!
Faith, I must say so; you may think I love you,
I breathe not rougher spite to sever us;
We’ll meet by stealth, sweet friends, by stealth you twain;
Kisses are sweetest got with struggling pain.

speech.speaker: Y. JERN.
speech.line: Our friendship dies not, Raymond.

speech.speaker: RAYM.
speech.line: Pardon me:
I am busied; I have lost my faculties,
And buried them in Millicent’s clear eyes.

speech.speaker: MIL.
speech.line: Alas, sweet love, what shall become of me?
I must to Cheston to the nunnery,
I shall ne’er see thee more.

speech.speaker: RAYM.
speech.line: How, sweet?
I’ll be thy votary, we’ll often meet:
This kiss divides us, and breathes soft adieu,—
This be a double charm to keep both true.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Have done: your fathers may chance spy your parting.
Refuse not you by any means, good sweetness,
To go unto the nunnery; far from hence
Must we beget your love’s sweet happiness.
You shall not stay there long; your harder bed
Shall be more soft when nun and maid are dead.

speech.speaker: RAYM.
speech.line: Now, sirrah, what’s the matter?

speech.speaker: BILB.
speech.line: Marry, you must to horse presently. That villainous old gouty churl, Sir Arthur Clare, longs till he be at the nunnery.

speech.speaker: Y. CLARE.
speech.line: How, sir?

speech.speaker: BILB.
speech.line: O, I cry you mercy, he is your father, sir, indeed; but I am sure that there’s less affinity betwixt your two natures than there is between a broker and a cutpurse.

speech.speaker: RAYM.
speech.line: Bring my gelding, sirrah.

speech.speaker: BILB.
speech.line: Well, nothing grieves me, but for the poor wench; she must now cry vale to lobster-pies, artichokes, and all such meats of mortality. Poor gentlewoman! The sign must not be in Virgo any longer with her, and that me grieves full well.
Poor Millicent
Must pray and repent:
O fatal wonder!
She’ll now be no fatter,
Love must not come at her,
Yet she shall be kept under.

speech.speaker: Y. JERN.
speech.line: Farewell, dear Raymond.

speech.speaker: Y. CLARE.
speech.line: Friend, adieu.

speech.speaker: MIL.
speech.line: Dear sweet,
No joy enjoys my heart till we next meet.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Well, Raymond, now the tide of discontent
Beats in thy face; but, ere’t be long, the wind
Shall turn the flood. We must to Waltham Abbey,
And as fair Millicent in Cheston lives,
A most unwilling nun, so thou shalt there
Become a beardless novice; to what end,
Let time and future accidents declare:
Taste thou my sleights, thy love I’ll only share.

speech.speaker: RAYM.
speech.line: Turn friar? Come, my good counselor, let’s go,
Yet that disguise will hardly shroud my woe.

stagedir.dir: Enter the Prioress of Cheston, with a nun or two, Sir Arthur Clare, Sir Ralph Jerningham, Henry and Frank, the Lady, and Bilbo, with Millicent.

speech.speaker: L. DOR.
speech.line: Madam,
The love unto this holy sisterhood,
And our confirm’d opinion of your zeal,
Hath truly won us to bestow our child
Rather on this than any neighboring cell.

speech.speaker: PRI.
speech.line: Jesus’ daughter, Mary’s child,
Holy matron, woman mild,
For thee a mass shall still be said,
Every Sister drop a bead;
And those again succeeding them
For you shall sing a requiem.

speech.speaker: Y. JERN.
speech.line: The wench is gone, Harry; she is no more a woman of this world. Mark her well, she looks like a nun already. What think’st on her?

speech.speaker: Y. CLARE.
speech.line: By my faith, her face comes handsomely to ’t.
But peace, let’s hear the rest.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Madam, for a twelvemonth’s approbation,
We mean to make this trial of our child.
Your care and our dear blessing, in meantime,
We pray, may prosper this intended work.

speech.speaker: PRI.
speech.line: May your happy soul be blithe,
That so truly pay your tithe:
He who many children gave,
’Tis fit that He one child should have.
Then, fair virgin, hear my spell,
For I must your duty tell.

speech.speaker: MIL.
speech.line: Good men and true, stand together, and hear your charge!

speech.speaker: PRI.
speech.line: First, a-mornings take your book,
The glass wherein yourself must look;
Your young thoughts, so proud and jolly,
Must be turned to motions holy;
For your busk, attires, and toys,
Have your thoughts on heavenly joys;
And for all your follies past
You must do penance, pray, and fast.

speech.speaker: BILB.
speech.line: Let her take heed of fasting; and if ever she hurt herself with praying, I’ll ne’er trust beast.

speech.speaker: MIL.
speech.line: This goes hard, by ’r Lady!

speech.speaker: PRI.
speech.line: You shall ring the sacring bell,
Keep your hours, and toll your knell,
Rise at midnight to your matins,
Read your Psalter, sing your Latins,
And when your blood shall kindle pleasure
Scourge yourself in plenteous measure.

speech.speaker: MIL.
speech.line: Worse and worse, by Saint Mary!

speech.speaker: Y. JERN.
speech.line: Sirrah Hal, how does she hold her countenance? Well, go thy ways, if ever thou prove a nun, I’ll build an Abbey.

speech.speaker: Y. CLARE.
speech.line: She may be a nun; but if ever she prove an anchoress, I’ll dig her grave with my nails.

speech.speaker: Y. JERN.
speech.line: To her again, mother!

speech.speaker: Y. CLARE.
speech.line: Hold thine own, wench!

speech.speaker: PRI.
speech.line: You must read the morning’s mass,
You must creep unto the cross,
Put cold ashes on your head,
Have a hair-cloth for your bed.

speech.speaker: BILB.
speech.line: She had rather have a man in her bed.

speech.speaker: PRI.
speech.line: Bid your beads, and tell your needs,
Your holy aves, and your creeds;
Holy maid, this must be done,
If you mean to live a nun.

speech.speaker: MIL.
speech.line: The holy maid will be no nun.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Madam, we have some business of import,
And must be gone.
Will’t please you take my wife into your closet,
Who further will acquaint you with my mind;
And so, good madam, for this time adieu.

speech.speaker: RALP.
speech.line: Well now, Frank Jerningham, how sayest thou?
To be brief,—
What wilt thou say for all this, if we two
Her father and myself, can bring about,
That we convert this nun to be a wife,
And thou the husband to this pretty nun?
How then, my lad? Ha, Frank, it may be done.

speech.speaker: Y. CLARE.
speech.line: Ay, now it works.

speech.speaker: Y. JERN.
speech.line: O God, sir, you amaze me at your words;
Think with yourself, sir, what a thing it were
To cause a recluse to remove her vow:
A maimed, contrite, and repentant soul,
Ever mortified with fasting and with prayer,
Whose thoughts, even as her eyes, are fix’d on heaven,
To draw a virgin, thus devour’d with zeal,
Back to the world: O impious deed!
Nor by the canon law can it be done
Without a dispensation from the Church;
Besides, she is so prone unto this life,
As she’ll even shriek to hear a husband nam’d.

speech.speaker: BILB.
speech.line: Ay, a poor innocent she! Well, here’s no knavery; he flouts the old fools to their teeth.

speech.speaker: RALP.
speech.line: Boy, I am glad to hear
Thou mak’st such scruple of that conscience;
And in a man so young as in yourself,
I promise you ’tis very seldom seen.
But Frank, this is a trick, a mere device,
A sleight plotted betwixt her father and myself,
To thrust Mounchensey’s nose beside the cushion;
That, being thus debarr’d of all access,
Time yet may work him from her thoughts,
And give thee ample scope to thy desires.

speech.speaker: BILB.
speech.line: A plague on you both, for a couple of Jews!

speech.speaker: Y. CLARE.
speech.line: How now, Frank, what say you to that?

speech.speaker: Y. JERN.
speech.line: Let me alone, I warrant thee.
Sir, assur’d that this motion doth proceed
From your most kind and fatherly affection,
I do dispose my liking to your pleasure:
But for it is a matter of such moment
As holy marriage, I must crave thus much,
To have some conference with my ghostly father,
Friar Hildersham, here by, at Waltham Abbey,
To be absolv’d of things, that it is fit
None only but my confessor should know.

speech.speaker: RALP.
speech.line: With all my heart. He is a reverend man; and tomorrow morning we will meet all at the Abbey, where by the opinion of that reverend man we will proceed. I like it passing well.
Till then we part, boy. Ay, think of it; farewell!
A parent’s care no mortal tongue can tell.

stagedir.dir: Enter Sir Arthur Clare, and Raymond Mounchensey, like a Friar.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Holy young novice, I have told you now
My full intent, and do refer the rest
To your professed secrecy and care:
And see,
Our serious speech hath stolen upon the way,
That we are come unto the Abbey gate.
Because I know Mounchensey is a fox,
That craftily doth overlook my doings,
I’ll not be seen, not I; tush, I have done,
I had a daughter, but she’s now a nun.
Farewell, dear son, farewell.

speech.speaker: RAYM.
speech.line: Fare you well!—Ay, you have done!
Your daughter, sir, shall not be long a nun.
O my rare tutor, never mortal brain
Plotted out such a mass of policy;
And my dear bosom is so great with laughter,
Begot by his simplicity and error,
My soul is fallen in labor with her joy.
O my true friends, Frank Jerningham and Clare,
Did you now know but how this jest takes fire—
That good Sir Arthur, thinking me a novice,
Had even pour’d himself into my bosom,
O, you would vent your spleens with tickling mirth!
But, Raymond, peace, and have an eye about,
For fear perhaps some of the nuns look out.
Peace and charity within,
Never touch’d with deadly sin;
I cast my holy water pure
On this wall and on this door,
That from evil shall defend,
And keep you from the ugly fiend:
Evil spirit, by night nor day,
Shall approach or come this way;
Elf nor fairy, by this grace,
Day nor night shall haunt this place.
Holy maidens!
Who’s that which knocks? Ha, who is there?

speech.speaker: RAYM.
speech.line: Gentle nun, here is a friar.

speech.speaker: NUN.
speech.line: A friar without, now Christ us save!
Holy man, what wouldst thou have?

speech.speaker: RAYM.
speech.line: Holy maid, I hither come
From Friar and Father Hildersham,
By the favor and the grace
Of the Prioress of this place
Amongst you all to visit one
That’s come for approbation;
Before she was as now you are,
The daughter of Sir Arthur Clare.
But since she now became a nun,
Call’d Millicent of Edmonton.

speech.speaker: NUN.
speech.line: Holy man, repose you there;
This news I’ll to our Abbess bear,
To tell her what a man is sent,
And your message and intent.

speech.speaker: RAYM.
speech.line: Benedicite.

speech.speaker: NUN.
speech.line: Benedicite.

speech.speaker: RAYM.
speech.line: Do, my good plump wench; if all fall right,
I’ll make your sisterhood one less by night.
Now happy fortune speed this merry drift,
I like a wench comes roundly to her shrift.

speech.speaker: L. DOR.
speech.line: Have friars recourse then to the house of nuns?

speech.speaker: MIL.
speech.line: Madam, it is the order of this place,
When any virgin comes for approbation,—
Lest that for fear or such sinister practice
She should be forc’d to undergo this veil,
Which should proceed from conscience and devotion,—
A visitor is sent from Waltham House,
To take the true confession of the maid.

speech.speaker: L. DOR.
speech.line: Is that the order? I commend it well:
You to your shrift, I’ll back unto the cell.

speech.speaker: RAYM.
speech.line: Life of my soul! Bright angel!

speech.speaker: MIL.
speech.line: What means the friar?

speech.speaker: RAYM.
speech.line: O Millicent, ’tis I.

speech.speaker: MIL.
speech.line: My heart misgives me; I should know that voice.
You? Who are you? The Holy Virgin bless me!
Tell me your name: you shall, ere you confess me.

speech.speaker: RAYM.
speech.line: Mounchensey, thy true friend.

speech.speaker: MIL.
speech.line: My Raymond, my dear heart!
Sweet life, give leave to my distracted soul,
To wake a little from this swoon of joy.
By what means cam’st thou to assume this shape?

speech.speaker: RAYM.
speech.line: By means of Peter Fabel, my kind tutor,
Who in the habit of Friar Hildersham,
Frank Jerningham’s old friend and confessor,
Plotted by Frank, by Fabel and myself,
And so delivered to Sir Arthur Clare,
Who brought me here unto the Abbey gate,
To be his nun-made daughter’s visitor.

speech.speaker: MIL.
speech.line: You are all sweet traitors to my poor old father.
O my dear life! I was a-dream’d tonight
That, as I was a-praying in mine Psalter,
There came a spirit unto me as I kneel’d,
And by his strong persuasions tempted me
To leave this nunnery: and methought
He came in the most glorious angel-shape,
That mortal eye did ever look upon.
Ha, thou art sure that spirit, for there’s no form
Is in mine eye so glorious as thine own.

speech.speaker: RAYM.
speech.line: O thou idolatress, that dost this worship
To him whose likeness is but praise of thee!
Thou bright, unsetting star, which through this veil,
For very envy, mak’st the sun look pale!

speech.speaker: MIL.
speech.line: Well, visitor, lest that perhaps my mother
Should think the friar too strict in his decrees,
I this confess to my sweet ghostly father:
If chaste pure love be sin, I must confess,
I have offended three years now with thee.

speech.speaker: RAYM.
speech.line: But do you yet repent you of the same?

speech.speaker: MIL.
speech.line: I’faith, I cannot.

speech.speaker: RAYM.
speech.line: Nor will I absolve thee
Of that sweet sin, though it be venial;
Yet have the penance of a thousand kisses,
And I enjoin you to this pilgrimage:
That in the evening you bestow yourself
Here in the walk near to the willow ground,
Where I’ll be ready both with men and horse
To wait your coming, and convey you hence
Unto a lodge I have in Enfield Chase.
No more reply, if that you yield consent—
I see more eyes upon our stay are bent.

speech.speaker: MIL.
speech.line: Sweet life, farewell! ’Tis done: let that suffice;
What my tongue fails, I send thee by mine eyes.

speech.speaker: Y. JERN.
speech.line: Now, visitor, how does this new-made nun?

speech.speaker: Y. CLARE.
speech.line: Come, come, how does she, noble Capuchin?

speech.speaker: RAYM.
speech.line: She may be poor in spirit, but for the flesh,
’Tis fat and plump, boys. Ah, rogues, there is
A company of girls would turn you all friars.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: But how, Mounchensey, how, lad, for the wench?

speech.speaker: RAYM.
speech.line: Zounds, lads, i’faith, I thank my holy habit,
I have confessed her, and the Lady Prioress
Hath given me ghostly counsel with her blessing.
And how say ye, boys,
If I be chose the weekly visitor?

speech.speaker: Y. CLARE.
speech.line: ’Sblood, she’ll have ne’er a nun unbag’d to sing mass then.

speech.speaker: Y. JERN.
speech.line: The Abbot of Waltham will have as many children to put to nurse as he has calves in the marsh.

speech.speaker: RAYM.
speech.line: Well, to be brief, the nun will soon at night turn tippet. If I can but devise to quit her cleanly of the nunnery, she is mine own.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: But, sirrah Raymond,
What news of Peter Fabel at the house?

speech.speaker: RAYM.
speech.line: Tush, he’s the only man; a necromancer and a conjurer that works for young Mounchensey altogether; and if it be not for Friar Benedick, that he can cross him by his learned skill, the wench is gone; Fabel will fetch her out by very magic.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Stands the wind there, boy? Keep them in that key,
The wench is ours before tomorrow day.
Well, Harry and Frank, as ye are gentlemen,
Stick to us close this once! You know your fathers
Have men and horse lie ready still at Cheston,
To watch the coast be clear, to scout about,
And have an eye unto Mounchensey’s walks:
Therefore you two may hover thereabouts,
And no man will suspect you for the matter;
Be ready but to take her at our hands,
Leave us to scamble for her getting out.

speech.speaker: Y. JERN.
speech.line: ’Sblood, if all Hertfordshire were at our heels,
We’ll carry her away in spite of them.

speech.speaker: Y. CLARE.
speech.line: But whither, Raymond?

speech.speaker: RAYM.
speech.line: To Brian’s upper lodge in Enfield Chase;
He is mine honest friend and a tall keeper;
I'’l send my man unto him presently
T’acquaint him with your coming and intent.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Be brief and secret!

speech.speaker: RAYM.
speech.line: Soon at night remember
You bring your horses to the willow ground.

speech.speaker: Y. JERN.
speech.line: ’Tis done; no more!

speech.speaker: Y. CLARE.
speech.line: We will not fail the hour.
My life and fortune now lies in your power.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: About our business! Raymond, let’s away!
Think of your hour; it draws well of the day.

stagedir.dir: Enter Blague, Banks, Smug, and Sir John.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Come, ye Hungarian pilchers, we are once more come under the zona torrida of the forest. Let’s be resolute, let’s fly to and again; and if the devil come, we’ll put him to his interrogatories, and not budge a foot. What? ’Sfoot, I’ll put fire into you, ye shall all three serve the good Duke of Norfolk.

speech.speaker: SMUG.
speech.line: Mine host, my bully, my precious consul, my noble Holofernes, I have been drunk i’ thy house twenty times and ten; all’s for that: I was last night in the third heavens, my brain was poor, it had yeast in ’t; but now I am a man of action; is ’t not so, lad?

speech.speaker: BANKS.
speech.line: Why, now thou hast two of the liberal sciences about thee, wit and reason, thou may’st serve the Duke of Europe.

speech.speaker: SMUG.
speech.line: I will serve the Duke of Christendom, and do him more credit in his cellar then all the plate in his buttery; is ’t not so, lad?

speech.speaker: JOHN.
speech.line: Mine host and Smug, stand there; Banks, you and your horse keep together; but lie close, show no tricks, for fear of the keeper. If we be scared, we’ll meet in the church porch at Enfield.

speech.speaker: SMUG.
speech.line: Content, Sir John.

speech.speaker: BANKS.
speech.line: Smug, dost not thou remember the tree thou fell’st out of last night?

speech.speaker: SMUG.
speech.line: Tush, an ’t had been as high as the Abbey, I should ne’er have hurt myself. I have fallen into the river, coming home from Waltham, and ’scaped drowning.

speech.speaker: JOHN.
speech.line: Come, sever, fear no sprits! We’ll have a buck presently. We have watched later than this for a doe, mine host.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Thou speak’st as true as velvet.

speech.speaker: JOHN.
speech.line: Why then, come! Grass and hay, etc.

speech.speaker: Y. CLARE.
speech.line: Frank Jerningham!

speech.speaker: Y. JERN.
speech.line: Speak softly, rogue; how now?

speech.speaker: Y. CLARE.
speech.line: ’Sfoot, we shall lose our way, it’s so dark; whereabouts are we?

speech.speaker: Y. JERN.
speech.line: Why, man, at Potter’s gate; the way lies right: hark! The clock strikes at Enfield. What’s the hour?

speech.speaker: Y. CLARE.
speech.line: Ten, the bell says.

speech.speaker: Y. JERN.
speech.line: A lie’s in ’s throat, it was but eight when we set out of Cheston. Sir John and his sexton are at ale tonight, the clock runs at random.

speech.speaker: Y. CLARE.
speech.line: Nay, as sure as thou liv’st, the villainous vicar is abroad in the Chase this dark night: the stone priest steals more venison than half the country.

speech.speaker: Y. JERN.
speech.line: Millicent, how dost thou?

speech.speaker: MIL.
speech.line: Sir, very well.
I would to God we were at Brian’s lodge.

speech.speaker: Y. CLARE.
speech.line: We shall anon; zounds, hark! What means this noise?

speech.speaker: Y. JERN.
speech.line: Stay, I hear horsemen.

speech.speaker: Y. CLARE.
speech.line: I hear footmen too.

speech.speaker: Y. JERN.
speech.line: Nay, then I have it. We have been discovered,
And we are followed by our fathers’ men.

speech.speaker: MIL.
speech.line: Brother and friend, alas, what shall we do?

speech.speaker: Y. CLARE.
speech.line: Sister, speak softly, or we are descried.
They are hard upon us, whatsoe’er they be;
Shadow yourself behind this brake of fern,
We’ll get into the wood, and let them pass.

stagedir.dir: Clare and Jerningham hide in one place, Millicent in another.
Enter Sir John, Blague, Smug, and Banks, one after another.

speech.speaker: JOHN.
speech.line: Grass and hay! We are all mortal; the keeper’s abroad, and there’s an end.

speech.speaker: BANKS.
speech.line: Sir John!

speech.speaker: JOHN.
speech.line: Neighbor Banks, what news?

speech.speaker: BANKS.
speech.line: Zwounds, Sir John, the keepers are abroad; I was hard by ’em.

speech.speaker: JOHN.
speech.line: Grass and hay! Where’s mine host Blague?

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Here, Metropolitan. The Philistines are upon us, be silent; let us serve the good Duke of Norfolk. But where is Smug?

speech.speaker: SMUG.
speech.line: Here; a pox on ye all, dogs. I have killed the greatest buck in Brian’s walk. Shift for yourselves, all the keepers are up. Let’s meet in Enfield church porch; away, we are all taken else.

stagedir.dir: Exeunt Sir John, Blague, Smug, and Banks.
Enter Brian, with Ralph, his man, and his hound.

speech.speaker: BRI.
speech.line: Ralph, hear’st thou any stirring?

speech.speaker: RALPH.
speech.line: I heard one speak here hard by, in the bottom. Peace, master, speak low. Zounds, if I did not hear a bow go off, and the buck bray, I never heard deer in my life.

speech.speaker: BRI.
speech.line: When went your fellows out into their walks?

speech.speaker: RALPH.
speech.line: An hour ago.

speech.speaker: BRI.
speech.line: ’Slife, is there stealers abroad, and they cannot hear
Of them: where the devil are my men tonight?
Sirrah, go up the wind towards Buckley’s lodge!
I’ll cast about the bottom with my hound,
And I will meet thee under coney oak.

speech.speaker: RALPH.
speech.line: I will, sir.

speech.speaker: BRI.
speech.line: How now? By the mass, my hound stays upon something;
Hark, hark, Bowman, hark, hark, there!

speech.speaker: MIL.
speech.line: Brother, Frank Jerningham, brother Clare!

speech.speaker: BRI.
speech.line: Peace. That’s a woman’s voice! Stand! Who’s there?
Stand, or I’ll shoot.

speech.speaker: MIL.
speech.line: O Lord! Hold your hands, I mean no harm, sir.

speech.speaker: BRI.
speech.line: Speak, who are you?

speech.speaker: MIL.
speech.line: I am a maid, sir. Who? Master Brian?

speech.speaker: BRI.
speech.line: The very same. Sure, I should know her voice;
Mistress Millicent?

speech.speaker: MIL.
speech.line: Ay, it is I, sir.

speech.speaker: BRI.
speech.line: God for his passion! What make you here alone?
I looked for you at my lodge an hour ago.
What means your company to leave you thus?
Who brought you hither?

speech.speaker: MIL.
speech.line: My brother, sir, and Master Jerningham,
Who, hearing folks about us in the Chase,
Feared it had been Sir Ralph and my father,
Who had pursued us, thus dispersed ourselves,
Till they were past us.

speech.speaker: BRI.
speech.line: But where be they?

speech.speaker: MIL.
speech.line: They be not far off, here about the grove.

stagedir.dir: Enter Clare and Jerningham from their hiding location.

speech.speaker: Y. CLARE.
speech.line: Be not afraid! Man, I heard Brian’s tongue,
That’s certain.

speech.speaker: Y. JERN.
speech.line: Call softly for your sister.

speech.speaker: Y. CLARE.
speech.line: Millicent!

speech.speaker: MIL.
speech.line: Ay, brother, here.

speech.speaker: BRI.
speech.line: Master Clare!

speech.speaker: Y. CLARE.
speech.line: I told you it was Brian.

speech.speaker: BRI.
speech.line: Who’s that? Master Jerningham? You are a couple of hot-shots. Does a man commit his wench to you, to put her to grass at this time of night?

speech.speaker: Y. JERN.
speech.line: We heard a noise about here in the chase,
And fearing that our fathers had pursued us,
Severed ourselves.

speech.speaker: Y. CLARE.
speech.line: Brian, how happ’d’st thou on her?

speech.speaker: BRI.
speech.line: Seeking for stealers are abroad tonight,
My hound stay’d on her, and so found her out.

speech.speaker: Y. CLARE.
speech.line: They were these stealers that affrighted us;
I was hard upon them, when they hors’d their deer,
And I perceive they took me for a keeper.

speech.speaker: BRI.
speech.line: Which way took they?

speech.speaker: Y. JERN.
speech.line: Towards Enfield.

speech.speaker: BRI.
speech.line: A plague upon ’t, that’s that damned priest, and Blague of the George—he that serves the good Duke of Norfolk.

speech.speaker: Y. CLARE.
speech.line: Peace, that’s my father’s voice.

speech.speaker: BRI.
speech.line: Zounds, you suspected them, and now they are here indeed.

speech.speaker: MIL.
speech.line: Alas, what shall we do?

speech.speaker: BRI.
speech.line: If you go to the lodge, you are surely taken;
Strike down the wood to Enfield presently,
And if Mounchensey come, I’ll send him t’ye.
Let me alone to bustle with your fathers;
I warrant you that I will keep them play
Till you have quit the Chase; away, away!
Who’s there?

stagedir.dir: Enter the two knights, Sir Ralph and Sir Arthur.

speech.speaker: RALP.
speech.line: In the king’s name, pursue the ravisher!

speech.speaker: BRI.
speech.line: Stand, or I’ll shoot.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Who’s there?

speech.speaker: BRI.
speech.line: I am the keeper that do charge you stand;
You have stolen my deer.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: We stolen thy deer? We do pursue a thief.

speech.speaker: BRI.
speech.line: You are arrant thieves, and ye have stolen my deer.

speech.speaker: RALP.
speech.line: We are knights; Sir Arthur Clare, and Sir Ralph Jerningham.

speech.speaker: BRI.
speech.line: The more your shame, that knights should be such thieves.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Who or what art thou?

speech.speaker: BRI.
speech.line: My name is Brian, keeper of this walk.

speech.speaker: RALP.
speech.line: O Brian, a villain!
Thou hast receiv’d my daughter to thy lodge.

speech.speaker: BRI.
speech.line: You have stolen the best deer in my walk tonight. My deer!

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: My daughter!
Stop not my way!

speech.speaker: BRI.
speech.line: What make you in my walk?
You have stolen the best buck in my walk tonight.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: My daughter!

speech.speaker: BRI.
speech.line: My deer!

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Where is Mounchensey?

speech.speaker: BRI.
speech.line: Where’s my buck?

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: I will complain me of thee to the king.

speech.speaker: BRI.
speech.line: I’ll complain unto the king you spoil his game:
’Tis strange that men of your account and calling
Will offer it!
I tell you true, Sir Arthur and Sir Ralph,
That none but you have only spoiled my game.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: I charge you, stop us not!

speech.speaker: BRI.
speech.line: I charge you both ye get out of my ground!
Is this a time for such as you,
Men of your place and of your gravity,
To be abroad a-thieving? ’Tis a shame;
And, afore God, if I had shot at you,
I had served you well enough.

scene.scenelocation: In the yard of Enfield Church.
scene.scenetime: About an hour later at 9 o’clock.

stagedir.dir: Enter Banks the Miller, wet on his legs.

speech.speaker: BANKS.
speech.line: ’Sfoot, here’s a dark night indeed! I think I have been in fifteen ditches between this and the forest. Soft, here’s Enfield Church. I am so wet with climbing over into an orchard for to steal some filberts. Well, here I’ll sit in the church porch, and wait for the rest of my consort.

speech.speaker: SAL.
speech.line: Here’s a sky as black as Lucifer, God bless us! Here was goodman Theophilus buried. He was the best nutcracker that ever dwelt in Enfield. Well, ’tis nine o’ clock, ’tis time to ring curfew. Lord bless us, what a white thing is that in the church porch! O Lord, my legs are too weak for my body, my hair is too stiff for my nightcap, my heart fails. This is the ghost of Theophilus. O Lord, it follows me! I cannot say my prayers, an one would give me a thousand pound. Good spirit, I have bowled and drunk and followed the hounds with you a thousand times, though I have not the spirit now to deal with you. O Lord!

speech.speaker: JOHN.
speech.line: Grass and hay! We are all mortal. Who’s there?

speech.speaker: SAL.
speech.line: We are grass and hay indeed; I know you to be Master Parson by your phrase.

speech.speaker: JOHN.
speech.line: Sexton!

speech.speaker: SAL.
speech.line: Ay, sir!

speech.speaker: JOHN.
speech.line: For mortality’s sake, what’s the matter?

speech.speaker: SAL.
speech.line: O Lord, I am a man of another element; Master Theophilus’ ghost is in the church porch. There was a hundred cats, all fire, dancing here even now, and they clomb up to the top of the steeple; I’ll not into the belfry for a world.

speech.speaker: JOHN.
speech.line: O good Salomon; I have been about a deed of darkness tonight: O Lord, I saw fifteen spirits in the forest, like white bulls; if I lie, I am an arrant thief: mortality haunts us—grass and hay! The devil’s at our heels, and let’s hence to the parsonage.

stagedir.dir: The Miller comes out very softly.

speech.speaker: BANKS.
speech.line: What noise was that? ’Tis the watch, sure. That villainous unlucky rogue, Smug, is ta’en, upon my life, and then all our villany comes out; I heard one cry, sure.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: If I go steal any more venison, I am a paradox! ’Sfoot, I can scarcely bear the sin of my flesh in the day, ’tis so heavy; if I turn not honest and serve the good Duke of Norfolk, as true mareterraneum skinker should do, let me never look higher than the element of a constable.

speech.speaker: BANKS.
speech.line: By the Lord, there are some watchmen; I hear them name Master Constable; I would to God my mill were an eunuch, and wanted her stones, so I were hence

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Who’s there?

speech.speaker: BANKS.
speech.line: ’Tis the constable, by this light; I’ll steal hence, and if I can meet mine host Blague, I’ll tell him how Smug is ta’en, and will him to look to himself.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: What the devil is that white thing? This same is a churchyard, and I have heard that ghosts and villainous goblins have been seen here.

speech.speaker: JOHN.
speech.line: Grass and hay! O that I could conjure! We saw a spirit here in the churchyard; and in the fallow field there’s the devil with a man’s body upon his back in a white sheet.

speech.speaker: SAL.
speech.line: It may be a woman’s body, Sir John.

speech.speaker: JOHN.
speech.line: If she be a woman, the sheets damn her; Lord bless us, what a night of mortality is this!

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Priest!

speech.speaker: JOHN.
speech.line: Mine host!

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Did you not see a spirit all in white cross you at the stile?

speech.speaker: SAL.
speech.line: O no, mine host: but there sat one in the porch; I have not breath enough left to bless me from the devil.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Who’s that?

speech.speaker: JOHN.
speech.line: The sexton, almost frighted out of his wits. Did you see Banks or Smug?

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: No, they are gone to Waltham, sure. I would fain hence; come, let’s to my house: I’ll ne’er serve the Duke of Norfolk in this fashion again whilst I breathe. If the devil be amongst us, ’tis time to hoist sail, and cry roomer. Keep together; sexton, thou art secret. What! Let’s be comfortable one to another.

speech.speaker: JOHN.
speech.line: We are all mortal, mine host.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: True; and I’ll serve God in the night hereafter afore the Duke of Norfolk.

stagedir.dir: Enter Sir Arthur Clare and Sir Ralph Jerningham, trussing their points as new up.

speech.speaker: RALP.
speech.line: Good morrow, gentle knight.
A happy day after your short night’s rest!

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Ha, ha, Sir Ralph, stirring so soon indeed?
By’r Lady, sir, rest would have done right well;
Our riding late last night has made me drowsy.
Go to, go to, those days are gone with us.

speech.speaker: RALP.
speech.line: Sir Arthur, Sir Arthur, care go with those days,
Let ’em even go together, let ’em go!
’Tis time, i’faith, that we were in our graves,
When children leave obedience to their parents,
When there’s no fear of God, no care, no duty.
Well, well, nay, nay, it shall not do, it shall not;
No, Mounchensey, thou’lt hear on’t, thou shalt,
Thou shalt i’faith!
I’ll hang thy son, if there be law in England.
A man’s child ravish’d from a nunnery!
This is rare!
Well, well, there’s one gone to Friar Hildersham.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Nay, gentle knight, do not vex thus, it will but hurt your health. You cannot grieve more than I do, but to what end? But hark you, Sir Ralph, I was about to say something—it makes no matter. But hark you in your ear. The Friar’s a knave, but God forgive me, a man cannot tell neither. ’Sfoot, I am so out of patience, I know not what to say.

speech.speaker: RALP.
speech.line: There’s one went for the Friar an hour ago. Comes he not yet? ’Sfoot, if I do find knavery under’s cowl, I’ll tickle him, I’ll firk him. Here, here, he’s here, he’s here. Good morrow, Friar; good morrow, gentle Friar.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Good morrow, Father Hildersham, good morrow.

speech.speaker: HIL.
speech.line: Good morrow, reverend knights, unto you both.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Father, how now? You hear how matters go;
I am undone, my child is cast away.
You did your best, at least I think the best;
But we are all cross’d; flatly, all is dash’d.

speech.speaker: HIL.
speech.line: Alas, good knights! How might the matter be?
Let me understand your grief for charity.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Who does not understand my griefs? Alas, alas!
And yet ye do not! Will the church permit
A nun in approbation of her habit
To be ravished?

speech.speaker: HIL.
speech.line: A holy woman, benedicite!
Now God forfend that any should presume
To touch the sister of a holy house.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Jesus deliver me!

speech.speaker: RALP.
speech.line: Why, Millicent, the daughter of this knight,
Is out of Cheston taken the last night.

speech.speaker: HIL.
speech.line: Was that fair maiden late become a nun?

speech.speaker: RALP.
speech.line: Was she, quotha? Knavery, knavery, knavery; I smell it, I smell it, i’faith; is the wind in that door? Is it even so? Dost thou ask me that now?

speech.speaker: HIL.
speech.line: It is the first time that I e’er heard of it.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: That’s very strange.

speech.speaker: RALP.
speech.line: Why, tell me, Friar, tell me. Thou art counted a holy man; do not play the hypocrite with me, nor bear with me. I cannot dissemble. Did I aught but by thy own consent, by thy allowance, nay, further, by thy warrant?

speech.speaker: HIL.
speech.line: Why, reverend Knight——

speech.speaker: RALP.
speech.line: Unreverend Friar——

speech.speaker: HIL.
speech.line: Nay, then give me leave, sir, to depart in quiet. I had hoped you had sent for me to some other end.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Nay, stay, good Friar; if anything hath happ’d
About this matter in thy love to us,
That thy strict order cannot justify,
Admit it be so, we will cover it.
Take no care, man:
Disclaim not yet thy counsel and advice,
The wisest man that is may be o’erreached.

speech.speaker: HIL.
speech.line: Sir Arthur, by my order and my faith,
I know not what you mean.

speech.speaker: RALP.
speech.line: By your order and your faith?
This is most strange of all. Why, tell me, Friar,
Are not you confessor to my son Frank?

speech.speaker: HIL.
speech.line: Yes, that I am.

speech.speaker: RALP.
speech.line: And did not this good knight here and myself
Confess with you, being his ghostly Father,
To deal with him about th’unbanded marriage
Betwixt him and that fair young Millicent?

speech.speaker: HIL.
speech.line: I never heard of any match intended.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Did not we break our minds that very time,
That our device of making her a nun
Was but a color and a very plot
To put by young Mounchensey? Is’t not true?

speech.speaker: HIL.
speech.line: The more I strive to know what you should mean,
The less I understand you.

speech.speaker: RALP.
speech.line: Did not you tell us still how Peter Fabel
At length would cross us, if we took not heed?

speech.speaker: HIL.
speech.line: I have heard of one that is a great magician,
But he’s about the university.

speech.speaker: RALP.
speech.line: Did not you send your novice Benedick
To persuade the girl to leave Mounchensey's love,
To cross that Peter Fabel in his art,
And to that purpose made him visitor?

speech.speaker: HIL.
speech.line: I never sent my novice from the house,
Nor have we made our visitation yet.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Never sent him? Nay, did he not go?
And did not I direct him to the house,
And confer with him by the way? And did he not
Tell me what charge he had received from you,
Word by word, as I requested at your hands?

speech.speaker: HIL.
speech.line: That you shall know; he came along with me,
And stays without. Come hither, Benedick!
Young Benedick, were you e’er sent by me
To Cheston Nunnery for a visitor?

speech.speaker: BEN.
speech.line: Never, sir, truly.

speech.speaker: RALP.
speech.line: Stranger than all the rest!

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Did not I direct you to the house? Confer with you
From Waltham Abbey unto Cheston wall?

speech.speaker: BEN.
speech.line: I never saw you, sir, before this hour!

speech.speaker: RALP.
speech.line: The devil thou didst not! Ho, chamberlain!

speech.speaker: CHAM.
speech.line: Anon, anon.

speech.speaker: RALP.
speech.line: Call mine host Blague hither!

speech.speaker: CHAM.
speech.line: I will send one over to see if he be up; I think he be scarce stirring yet.

speech.speaker: RALP.
speech.line: Why, knave, didst thou not tell me an hour ago mine host was up?

speech.speaker: CHAM.
speech.line: Ay, sir, my master’s up.

speech.speaker: RALP.
speech.line: You knave, is a up, and is a not up? Dost thou mock me?

speech.speaker: CHAM.
speech.line: Ay, sir, my master is up; but I think Master Blague indeed be not stirring.

speech.speaker: RALP.
speech.line: Why, who’s thy master? Is not the master of the house thy master?

speech.speaker: CHAM.
speech.line: Yes, sir. But Master Blague dwells over the way.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Is not this the George? Before God, there’s some villany in this.

speech.speaker: CHAM.
speech.line: ’Sfoot, our sign’s remov’d; this is strange!

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Chamberlain, speak up to the new lodgings, bid Nell look well to the baked meats!

stagedir.dir: Enter Sir Arthur and Sir Ralph.

speech.line: How now, my old jennets balk my house, my castle, lie in Waltham all night, and not under the canopy of your host Blague’s house?

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Mine host, mine host, we lay all night at the George in Waltham; but whether the George be your fee-simple or no, ’tis a doubtful question. Look upon your sign!

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Body of Saint George, this is mine overthwart neighbor hath done this to seduce my blind customers. I’ll tickle his catastrophe for this; if I do not indict him at next assizes for burglary, let me die of the yellows; for I see ’tis no boot in these days to serve the good Duke of Norfolk. The villainous world is turned manger; one jade deceives another, and your ostler plays his part commonly for the fourth share. Have we comedies in hand, you whoreson, villainous male London lecher?

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Mine host, we have had the moiling’st night of it that ever we had in our lives.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Is’t certain?

speech.speaker: RALP.
speech.line: We have been in the forest all night almost.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: ’Sfoot, how did I miss you? Heart, I was a-stealing a buck there.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: A plague on you;. We were stayed for you.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Were you, my noble Romans? Why, you shall share; the venison is a-footing. Sine Cerere et Baccho friget Venus; that is, there’s a good breakfast provided for a marriage that’s in my house this morning.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: A marriage, mine host?

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: ’Tis firm, ’tis done. We’ll show you a precedent i’ the civil law for’t.

speech.speaker: RALP.
speech.line: How? Married?

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Leave tricks and admiration. There’s a cleanly pair of sheets in the bed in orchard chamber, and they shall lie there. What? I’ll do it; I’ll serve the good Duke of Norfolk.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Thou shalt repent this, Blague.

speech.speaker: RALP.
speech.line: If any law in England will make thee smart for this, expect it with all severity.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: I renounce your defiance, if you parle so roughly. I’ll barracado my gates against you. Stand fair, bully; Priest, come off from the rearward! What can you say now? ’Twas done in my house; I have shelter i’th’ court for’t. D’ye see yon bay window? I serve the good Duke of Norfolk, and ’tis his lodging. Storm, I care not, serving the good Duke of Norfolk. Thou art an actor in this, and thou shalt carry fire in thy face eternally.

stagedir.dir: Enter Smug, Mounchensey, Harry Clare, Bilbo, Sir John, and Millicent.

speech.speaker: SMUG.
speech.line: Fire, ’sblood, there’s no fire in England like your Trinidado sack. Is any man here humorous? We stole the venison, and we’ll justify it: say you now!

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: In good sooth, Smug, there’s more sack on the fire, Smug.

speech.speaker: SMUG.
speech.line: I do not take any exceptions against your sack; but if you’ll lend me a pike-staff, I’ll cudgel them all hence, by this hand.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: I say thou shalt into the cellar.

speech.speaker: SMUG.
speech.line: ’Sfoot, mine host, shall’s not grapple? Pray, pray you; I could fight now for all the world like a cockatrice’s egg. Shall’s not serve the Duke of Norfolk?

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: In, skipper, in!

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Sirrah, hath young Mounchensey married your sister?

speech.speaker: Y. CLARE.
speech.line: ’Tis certain, sir; here’s the priest that coupled them, the parties joined, and the honest witness that cried Amen.

speech.speaker: RAYM.
speech.line: Sir Arthur Clare, my new created father,
I beseech you, hear me.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Sir, sir, you are a foolish boy; you have done that you cannot answer. I dare be bold to seize her from you; for she’s a professed nun.

speech.speaker: MIL.
speech.line: With pardon, sir, that name is quite undone;
This true love knot cancels both maid and nun.
When first you told me I should act that part,
How cold and bloody it crept o’er my heart!
To Cheston with a smiling brow I went;
But yet, dear sir, it was to this intent,
That my sweet Raymond might find better means
To steal me thence. In brief, disguised he came,
Like novice to old Father Hildersham:
His tutor here did act that cunning part,
And in our love hath joined much wit to art.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Is’t even so?

speech.speaker: MIL.
speech.line: With pardon therefore we entreat your smiles;
Love, thwarted, turns itself to thousand wiles.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Young Master Jerningham, were you an actor
In your own love’s abuse?

speech.speaker: Y. JERN.
speech.line: My thoughts, good sir,
Did labor seriously unto this end,
To wrong myself, ere I’d abuse my friend.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: He speaks like a bachelor of music, all in numbers. Knights, if I had known you would have let this covey of partridges sit thus long upon their knees under my sign-post, I would have spread my door with old coverlids.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Well, sir, for this your sign was removed, was it?

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Faith, we followed the directions of the devil, Master Peter Fabel; and Smug, Lord bless us! Could never stand upright since.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: You, sir, ’twas you was his minister that married them?

speech.speaker: JOHN.
speech.line: Sir, to prove myself an honest man, being that I was last night in the forest stealing venison—now, sir, to have you stand my friend, if that matter shou’d be called in question, I married your daughter to this worthy gentleman.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: I may chance to requite you, and make your neck crack for’t.

speech.speaker: JOHN.
speech.line: If you do, I am as resolute as my neighbor vicar of Waltham Abbey. Ahem, grass and hay! We are all mortal; let’s live till we be hang’d, mine host, and be merry; and there’s an end.

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Now, knights, I enter; now my part begins.
To end this difference, know, at first I knew
What you intended, ere your love took flight
From old Mounchensey; you, Sir Arthur Clare,
Were minded to have married this sweet beauty
To young Frank Jerningham; to cross which match,
I used some pretty sleights; but I protest
Such as but sat upon the skirts of art;
No conjurations, nor such weighty spells
As tie the soul to their performancy.
These for his love, who once was my dear pupil,
Have I effected. Now, methinks, ’tis strange
That you, being old in wisdom, should thus knit
Your forehead on this match, since reason fails;
No law can curb the lover’s rash attempt;
Years, in resisting this, are sadly spent.
Smile, then, upon your daughter and kind son,
And let our toil to future ages prove,
The Devil of Edmonton did good in love.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Well, ’tis in vain to cross the providence:
Dear son, I take thee up into my heart;
Rise, daughter; this is a kind father’s part.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Why, Sir John, send for Spindle’s noise, presently: ha, ere’t be night, I’ll serve the good Duke of Norfolk.

speech.speaker: JOHN.
speech.line: Grass and hay! Mine host, let’s live till we die, and be merry; and there’s an end.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: What, is breakfast ready, mine host?

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: ’Tis, my little Hebrew.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Sirrah, ride straight to Cheston Nunnery,
Fetch thence my lady; the house, I know,
By this time misses their young votary.
Come, knights, let’s in!

speech.speaker: BILB.
speech.line: I will to horse presently, sir.—A plague a my lady, I shall miss a good breakfast. Smug, how chance you cut so plaguily behind, Smug?

speech.speaker: SMUG.
speech.line: Stand away, I’ll founder you else.

speech.speaker: BILB.
speech.line: Farewell, Smug, thou art in another element.

speech.speaker: SMUG.
speech.line: I will be by and by; I will be Saint George again.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Take heed the fellow do not hurt himself.

speech.speaker: RALP.
speech.line: Did we not last night find two St. Georges here?

speech.speaker: FAB.
speech.line: Yes, knights, this martialist was one of them.

speech.speaker: Y. CLARE.
speech.line: Then thus conclude your night of merriment!
